Fast Flow Volume Estimation

Ran Ben Basat
Gil Einziger
Roy Friedman
Technion sran@cs.technion.ac.il Nokia Bell Labs gil.einziger@nokia.com Technion roy@cs.technion.ac.il
Abstract

The increasing popularity of jumbo frames means growing variance in the size of packets transmitted in modern networks. Consequently, network monitoring tools must maintain explicit traffic volume statistics rather than settle for packet counting as before. We present constant time algorithms for volume estimations in streams and sliding windows, which are faster than previous work. Our solutions are formally analyzed and are extensively evaluated over multiple real-world packet traces as well as synthetic ones. For streams, we demonstrate a run-time improvement of up to 2.4X compared to the state of the art. On sliding windows, we exhibit a memory reduction of over 100X on all traces and an asymptotic runtime improvement to a constant. Finally, we apply our approach to hierarchical heavy hitters and achieve an empirical 2.4-7X speedup.

â€ â€ conference: ICDCN â€™18 January 2018

1 Introduction

Traffic measurement is vital for many network algorithms such as routing, load balancing, quality of service, caching and anomaly/intrusion detectionÂ [28, 37, 20, 18]. Typically, networking devices handle millions of flowsÂ [41, 38]. Often, monitoring applications track the most frequently appearing flows, known as heavy hitters, as their impact is most significant.

Most works on heavy hitters identification have focused on packet countingÂ [3, 17, 42]. However, in recent years jumbo frames and large TCP packets are becoming increasingly popular and so the variability in packet sizes grows. Consequently, plain packet counting may no longer serve as a good approximation for bandwidth utilization. For example, in data collected byÂ [23] in 2014, less than 1%percent11\% of the packets account for over 25%percent2525\% of the total traffic. Here, packet count based heavy hitters algorithms might fail to identify some heavy hitter flows in terms of bandwidth consumption.

Hence, in this paper we explicitly address monitoring of flow volume rather than plain packet counting. Further, given the rapid line rates and the high volume of accumulating data, an aging mechanism such as a sliding window is essential for ensuring data freshness and the estimationâ€™s relevance. Hence, we study estimations of flow volumes in both streams and sliding windows.

Finally, per flow measurements are not enough for certain functionalities like anomaly detection and Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack detectionÂ [43, 40]. In such attacks, each attacking device only generates a small portion of the traffic and is not a heavy hitter. Yet, their combined traffic volume is overwhelming. Hierarchical heavy hitters (HHH) aggregates traffic from IP addresses that share some common prefixÂ [6]. In a DDoS, when attacking devices share common IP prefixes, HHH can discover the attack. To that end, we consider volume based HHH detection as well.

Before explaining our contribution, let us first motivate why packet counting solutions are not easily adaptable to volume estimation. Counter algorithms typically maintain a fixed set of countersÂ [35, 4, 34, 16, 39, 29, 3] that is considerably smaller than the number of flows. Ideally, counters are allocated to the heavy hitters. When a packet from an unmonitored flow arrives, the corresponding flow is allocated the minimal counterÂ [35] or a counter whose value has dropped below a dynamically increased thresholdÂ [34].

We refer to a stream in which each packet is associated with aweight is as a weighted stream. Similarly, we refer to streams without weights, or when all packets receive the same weight as unweighted. For unweighted streams, ordered data structures allow constant time updates and queriesÂ [35, 3], since when a counter is incremented, its relative order among all counters changes by at most one. Unfortunately, maintaining the counters sorted after a counter increment in a weighted stream either requires to search for its new location, which incurs a logarithmic cost, or resorting to logarithmic time data structures like heaps. The reason is that if the counter is incremented by some value wğ‘¤w, its relative position might change by up to wğ‘¤w positions. This difficulty motivates our work111 The most naive approach treats a packet of size wğ‘¤w as wğ‘¤w consecutive arrivals of the same packet in the unweighted case, resulting in linear update times, which is even worse..

1.1 Contributions

We contribute to the following network measurement problems: (i) stream heavy hitters, (ii) sliding window heavy hitters, (iii) stream hierarchical heavy hitters. Specifically, our first contribution is Frequent items Algorithm with a Semi-structured Table (FAST), a novel algorithm for monitoring flow volumes and finding heavy hitters. FAST processes elements in worst case Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) time using asymptotically optimal space. We formally prove and analyze the performance of FAST. We then evaluate FAST on 5 real Internet packet traces from a data center and backbone networks, demonstrating a 2.4X performance gain compared to previous works.

Our second contribution is Windowed Frequent items Algorithm with a Semi-structured Table (WFAST), a novel algorithm for monitoring flow volumes and finding heavy hitters in sliding windows. We evaluate WFAST on five Internet traces and show that its runtime is reasonably fast, and that it requires as little as 1%percent11\% of the memory of previous workÂ [27]. We analyze WFAST and show that it operates in constant time and is space optimal, which asymptotically improves both the runtime and the space consumption of previous work. We believe that such a dramatic improvement makes volume estimation over a sliding window practical!

Our third contribution is Hierarchical Frequent items Algorithm with a Semi-structured Table (HFAST), which finds hierarchical heavy hitters. HFAST is created by replacing the underlying HH algorithm inÂ [36] (Space Saving) with FAST. We evaluate HFAST and demonstrate an asymptotic update time improvement as well as an empirical 2.4-7X speedup on real Internet traces.

2 Related Work

2.1 Streams

Sketches such as Count Sketch (CS)Â [8] and Count Min Sketch (CMS)Â [15] are attractive as they enable counter sharing and need not maintain a flow to counter mapping for all flows. Sketches typically only provide a probabilistic estimation, and often do not store flow identifiers. Thus, they cannot find the heavy hitters, but only focus on the volume estimation problem. Advanced sketches, such as Counter BraidsÂ [32], Randomized Counter SharingÂ [31] and Counter TreeÂ [9], improve accuracy, but their queries require complex decoding.

In counter based algorithms, a flow table is maintained, but only a small number of flows are monitored. These algorithms differ from each other in the size and maintenance policy of the flow table, e.g.,Â Lossy CountingÂ [34] and its extensionsÂ [16, 39], FrequentÂ [29] and Space SavingÂ [35]. Given ideal conditions, counter algorithms are considered superior to sketch based techniques. Particularly, Space Saving was empirically shown to be the most accurateÂ [11, 12, 33]. Many counter based algorithms were developed by the databases community and are mostly suitable for software implementation. The work ofÂ [3] suggests a compact static memory implementation of Space Saving that may be more accessible for hardware design. Yet, software implementations are becoming increasingly relevant in networking as emerging technologies such as NFVs become popular.

Alas, most previous works rely on sorted data structures such as Stream SummaryÂ [35] or SAILÂ [3] that only operate in constant time for unweighted updates. Thus, a logarithmic time heap based implementation of Space Saving was suggestedÂ [12] for the more general volume counting problem. IM-SUM, DIM-SUMÂ [5] and BUS-SSÂ [19] are very recent algorithms developed for the volume heavy-hitters problem (only for streams, with no sliding windows support). BUS offers a randomized algorithm that operates in constant time. IM-SUM operates in amortized Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) time and DIM-SUM in worst case constant time. Empirically, DIM-SUM it is slower than FAST. Additionally, DIM-SUM requires 2+Ï•Ïµ2italic-Ï•italic-Ïµ\frac{2+\phi}{\epsilon} counters, for some Ï•>0italic-Ï•0\phi>0, for guaranteeing Nâ‹…Mâ‹…Ïµâ‹…ğ‘ğ‘€italic-ÏµN\cdot M\cdot\epsilon error and operating in Oâ€‹(Ï•âˆ’1)ğ‘‚superscriptitalic-Ï•1O(\phi^{-1}) time. FAST only needs half as many counters for the same time and error guarantees.

2.2 Sliding Windows

Heavy hitters on sliding windows were first studied byÂ [1]. Given an accuracy parameter (Îµ)ğœ€(\varepsilon), a window size (W)ğ‘Š(W) and a maximal increment size (Mğ‘€M), such algorithms estimate flowsâ€™ volume on the sliding window with an additive error that is at most Wâ‹…Mâ‹…Îµâ‹…ğ‘Šğ‘€ğœ€W\cdot M\cdot\varepsilon.

Their algorithm requires Oâ€‹(1Ïµâ€‹log2â¡1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-Ïµsuperscript21italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log^{2}\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right) counters and Oâ€‹(1Ïµâ€‹logâ¡1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-Ïµ1italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right) time for queries and updates. The work ofÂ [30] reduces the space requirements and update time to Oâ€‹(1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right). An improved algorithm with a constant update time is given inÂ [26]. Further, [3] provided an algorithm that requires Oâ€‹(1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right) for queries and supports constant time updates and item frequency queries.

The weighted variant of the problem was only studied byÂ [27], whose algorithm operates in Oâ€‹(AÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ´italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{A}{\epsilon}}\right) time and requires Oâ€‹(AÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ´italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{A}{\epsilon}}\right) space for a Wâ‹…Mâ‹…Îµâ‹…ğ‘Šğ‘€ğœ€W\cdot M\cdot\varepsilon approximation; here, Aâˆˆ[1,M]ğ´1ğ‘€A\in[1,M] is the average packet size in the window. In this work, we suggest an algorithm for the weighted problem that (iğ‘–i) uses optimal Oâ€‹(1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right) space, (iâ€‹iğ‘–ğ‘–ii) performs heavy hitters queries in optimal Oâ€‹(1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right) time, and (iii) performs volume queries and updates in constant time.

2.3 Hierarchical Heavy Hitters

Hierarchical Heavy Hitters (HHH) were addressed, e.g., inÂ [13, 14, 21, 43, 36]. HHH algorithms monitor aggregates of flows that share a common prefix. To do so, HHH algorithms treat flows identifiers as a hierarchical domain. We denote by Hğ»H the size of this domain.

The full and partial ancestry algorithmsÂ [14] are trie based algorithms that require Oâ€‹(HÏµâ€‹logâ¡Ïµâ€‹N)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµğ‘O\left(\frac{H}{\epsilon}\log\epsilon N\right) space and operate at Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡Ïµâ€‹N)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-Ïµğ‘O\left(H\log{\epsilon N}\right) time. The state of the artÂ [36] algorithm requires Oâ€‹(HÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-ÏµO\left(\frac{H}{\epsilon}\right) space and its update time for weighted inputs is Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡(1Ïµ))ğ‘‚ğ»1italic-ÏµO\left(H\log(\frac{1}{\epsilon})\right). It solves the approximate HHH problem by dividing it into multiple simpler heavy hitters problems. In our work, we replace the underlying heavy hitters algorithm ofÂ [36] with FAST, which yields a space complexity of Oâ€‹(HÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-ÏµO\left(\frac{H}{\epsilon}\right) and an update complexity of Oâ€‹(H)ğ‘‚ğ»O(H). That is, we improve the update complexity from Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡(1Ïµ))ğ‘‚ğ»1italic-ÏµO\left(H\log\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)\right) to Oâ€‹(H)ğ‘‚ğ»O\left(H\right).

4 Frequent items Algorithm with a Semi-structured Table (FAST)

In this section, we present Frequent items Algorithm with a Semi-structured Table (FAST), a novel algorithm that achieves constant time weighted updates. FAST uses a data structure called Semi Ordered Summary (SOS), which maintains flow entries in a semi ordered manner. That is, similarly to previous works, SOS groups flows according to their volume, each of which is called a volume group. The volume groups are maintained in an ordered list. Each volume group is associated with a value Cğ¶C that determines the volume of its nodes. Unlike existing data structures, counters within each volume group are kept unordered.

Unlike previous works, the grouping is done at coarse granularity. Each node (inside a group) includes a variable called Remainder (denoted Rğ‘…R). The volume estimate of a flow is C+Rğ¶ğ‘…C+R where Rğ‘…R is the remainder of its volume node and Cğ¶C is the value of its volume group.

This semi-ordered structure is unique to SOS and enables it to serve weighted updates in Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1). Volume queries are satisfied in constant time using a separate aggregate hash table which maps between each flow identifier and its SOS node. FAST then uses SOS to find a near-minimum flow when needed.

FigureÂ 1 provides an intuitive example for the case M=1,000ğ‘€1000M=1,000. Here, the volume of an item is calculated by both its group counter (Cğ¶C) and the itemâ€™s remainder (Rğ‘…R), e.g., the volume of A is 400+32=43240032432400+32=432. Flows are partially ordered according to their third digit, i.e., in multiples of 100100100, or M/10ğ‘€10M/10. Within a specific group, however, items are unordered, e.g., A, B and J are unordered but all appear before items with volume of at least 500500500. As the number of lists to skip prior to an addition is Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1), the update complexity is also Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1).

Intuitively, flows are only ordered according to volume groups and if we make sure that the maximal weight can only advance a flow a constant number of flow groups then SOS operates in constant time. Alas, keeping the flows only partially ordered increases the error. We compensate for such an increase by requiring a larger number of SOS entries compared to previously suggested fully ordered structures. The main challenge in realizing this idea is to analyze the accuracy impact and provide strong estimation guarantees.

4.1 FAST - Accurate Description

FAST employs âŒˆ1+Ï•ÏµâŒ‰1italic-Ï•italic-Ïµ\left\lceil{\frac{1+\phi}{\epsilon}}\right\rceil counters, for some non-negative constant Ï•â‰¥0italic-Ï•0\phi\geq 0. Ï•italic-Ï•\phi determines how ordered SOS is: for Ï•=0italic-Ï•0\phi=0, we get full order, while for Ï•>0italic-Ï•0\phi>0, it is only ordered up to Mâ‹…Ï•/2â‹…ğ‘€italic-Ï•2M\cdot\phi/2 (all flows that fall into the same volume group are unordered, and each group holds a range of Mâ‹…Ï•/2â‹…ğ‘€italic-Ï•2M\cdot\phi/2 values). The runtime is, however, Oâ€‹(1/Ï•)ğ‘‚1italic-Ï•O(1/\phi) and is therefore constant for any fixed Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. We note that an Î©â€‹(1Ïµ)Î©1italic-Ïµ\Omega\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right) counters lower bound is knownÂ [35]. Thus, FAST is asymptotically optimal for constant Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. The pseudo code of FAST appears in AlgorithmÂ 1.

Finally, FAST also solves the heavy hitters problem:

Theorem 3

For any fixed Ï•>0italic-Ï•0\phi>0, when allocated with â„­â‰œâ‰œâ„­absent\mathfrak{C}{}\triangleqâŒˆ1+Ï•ÏµâŒ‰1italic-Ï•italic-Ïµ\left\lceil{\frac{1+\phi}{\epsilon}}\right\rceil counters, by returning {xâˆˆğ’°âˆ£vx^â‰¥Nâ‹…Mâ‹…Î¸}conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’°^subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘ğ‘€ğœƒ\{x\in\mathcal{U}\mid\widehat{v_{x}}\geq N\cdot M\cdot\theta\}, FAST solves the (Î¸,Ïµ,M)ğœƒitalic-Ïµğ‘€(\theta,\epsilon,M)-Weighted Heavy Hitters problem.

5 Windowed FAST (WFAST)

We now present Windowed Frequent items Algorithm with a Semi-structured Table (WFAST), an efficient algorithm for the (W,Ïµ,M)ğ‘Šitalic-Ïµğ‘€{(W,\epsilon,M)}-Volume Estimation and (W,Î¸,Ïµ,M)ğ‘Šğœƒitalic-Ïµğ‘€{(W,\theta,\epsilon,M)}-Weighted Heavy Hitters problems.

We partition the stream into consecutive sequences of size Wğ‘ŠW called frames. Each frame is further divided into kâ‰œâŒˆ4ÏµâŒ‰â‰œğ‘˜4italic-Ïµk\triangleq\left\lceil{\frac{4}{\epsilon}}\right\rceil blocks, each of size Wkğ‘Šğ‘˜\frac{W}{k}, which we assume is an integer for simplicity. FigureÂ 2 illustrates the setting.

WFAST uses a FAST instance yğ‘¦y to estimate the volume of each flow within the current frame. Once a frame ends (the stream length is divisible by Wğ‘ŠW), we â€œflushâ€ the instance, i.e., reset all counters and remainders to 00. Yet, we do not â€œforgetâ€ all information in a flush, as high volume flows are stored in a dedicated data structure. Specifically, we say that an element xğ‘¥x overflowed at time tğ‘¡t if âŒŠqx,tMâ€‹W/kâŒ‹>âŒŠqx,tâˆ’1Mâ€‹W/kâŒ‹subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¡1ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘˜\left\lfloor{\frac{q_{x,t}}{MW/k}}\right\rfloor>\left\lfloor{\frac{q_{x,t-1}}{MW/k}}\right\rfloor. We use a queue of queues structure bğ‘b to keep track of which elements have overflowed in each block. That is, each node of the main queue represents a block and contains a queue of all elements that overflowed in its block. Particularly, the secondary queues maintain the ids of overflowing elements. Once a block ends, we remove the oldest blockâ€™s node (queue) from the main queue, and initialize a new queue for the starting block. Finally, we answer queries about the window volume of an item xğ‘¥x by multiplying its overflows count by Mâ€‹W/kğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘˜MW/k, adding the residual count from yğ‘¦y (i.e., the part that is not recorded in bğ‘b), plus 2â€‹Mâ€‹W/k2ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘˜2MW/k to ensure an overestimation.

For Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) time queries, we also maintain a hash table BğµB that tracks the overflow count for each item. That is, for each element xğ‘¥x, Bâ€‹[x]ğµdelimited-[]ğ‘¥B[x] contains the number of times xğ‘¥x is recorded in bğ‘b. Since multiple items may overflow in the same block, we cannot update BğµB once a block ends in constant time. We address this issue by deamortizing BğµBâ€™s update, and on each arrival we remove a single item from the queue of the oldest block (if such exists). The pseudo code of WFAST appears in AlgorithmÂ 2 and a list containing its variables description appears in TableÂ 2. An efficient implementation of the queue of queues bğ‘b is described inÂ [3].

5.1 WFAST Analysis

We start by introducing several notations to be used in this section. We mark the queried element by xğ‘¥x, the current time by W+oğ‘Šğ‘œW+o, and assume that item Wğ‘ŠW is the first element of the current frame. For convenience, denote vxâ€‹(t1,t2)â‰œâˆ‘iâˆˆ{t1,â€¦,t2}:xi=xwi,â‰œsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2subscript:ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡2absentsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–v_{x}(t_{1},t_{2})\triangleq\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i\in\left\{t_{1},\ldots,t_{2}\right\}:\\ x_{i}=x\end{subarray}}w_{i}, i.e., the volume of xğ‘¥x between t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1} and t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}. The goal is then to approximate the window volume of xğ‘¥x, which is defined as vxwâ‰œvâ€‹(o+1,W+o),â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¥ğ‘¤ğ‘£ğ‘œ1ğ‘Šğ‘œv_{x}^{w}\triangleq v(o+1,W+o), i.e., the sum of weights in the timestamps within âŸ¨o+1,o+2,â€¦,W+oâŸ©ğ‘œ1ğ‘œ2â€¦ğ‘Šğ‘œ\langle o+1,o+2,\ldots,W+o\rangle in which xğ‘¥x arrived. We next state the main correctness theorem for WFAST.

Theorem 4

AlgorithmÂ 2 solves the (W,Ïµ,M)ğ‘Šitalic-Ïµğ‘€{(W,\epsilon,M)}-Volume Estimation problem.

Due to lack of space, the proof of the Theorem appears in the Appendix.

As a corollary, AlgorithmÂ 2 can find heavy hitters.

Theorem 5

By returning all items xâˆˆğ’°ğ‘¥ğ’°x\in\mathcal{U} for which vxW^â‰¥Mâ€‹Wâ€‹Î¸^subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£ğ‘Šğ‘¥ğ‘€ğ‘Šğœƒ\widehat{v^{W}_{x}}\geq MW\theta, AlgorithmÂ 2 solves (W,Î¸,Ïµ,M)ğ‘Šğœƒitalic-Ïµğ‘€{(W,\theta,\epsilon,M)}-Weighted HeavyÂ Hitters.

WFAST runtime analysis:

As listed in the pseudo code of WFAST (see AlgorithmÂ 2) and the description above, processing new elements requires adding them to the FAST instance yğ‘¦y, which takes Oâ€‹(1Ï•)ğ‘‚1italic-Ï•O(\frac{1}{\phi}) time, and another Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) operations. The query processing includes Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) operations and hash tables accesses. For returning the heavy hitters, we go over all of the items with allocated counters in time Oâ€‹(1+Ï•Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-Ï•italic-ÏµO(\frac{1+\phi}{\epsilon}). In summary, we get the following theorem:

Theorem 6

For any fixed Ï•>0italic-Ï•0\phi>0, WFAST processes new elements and answers window-volume queries in constant time, while finding the windowâ€™s weighted heavy hitters in Oâ€‹(1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-ÏµO(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) time.

6 Hierarchical Heavy Hitters

Hierarchical heavy hitters (HHH) algorithms treat IP addresses as a hierarchical domain. At the bottom are fully specified IP addresses such as p0=101.102.103.104subscriptğ‘0101.102.103.104p_{0}=101.102.103.104. Higher layers include shorter and shorter prefixes of the fully specified addresses. For example, p1=101.102.103.âˆ—formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘1101.102.103p_{1}=101.102.103.* and p2=101.102.âˆ—formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘2101.102p_{2}=101.102.* are level 1 and level 2 prefixes of p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}, respectively. Such prefixes generalize an IP address. In this example, p0â‰ºp1â‰ºp2precedessubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1precedessubscriptğ‘2p_{0}\prec p_{1}\prec p_{2}, indicating that p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0} satisfies the pattern of p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}, and any IP address that satisfies p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1} also satisfies p2subscriptğ‘2p_{2}. The above example refers to a single dimension (e.g., the source IP), and can be generalized to multiple dimensions (e.g., pairs of source IP and destination IP). HHH algorithms need to find the heavy hitter prefixes at each level of the induced hierarchy. For example, this enables identifying heavy hitters subnets, which may be suspected of generating a DDoS attack. The problem is formally defined inÂ [36, 14].

Hierarchical Fast (HFAST)

Hierarchical FAST (HFAST) is derived from the algorithm ofÂ [36]. Specifically, the work ofÂ [36] suggests Hierarchical Space Saving with a Heap(HSSH). In their work, the HHH prefixes are distilled from multiple solutions of plain heavy hitter problems. That is, each prefix pattern has its own separate heavy hitters algorithm that is updated on each packet arrival. For example, consider a packet whose source IP address is 101.102.103.104101.102.103.104101.102.103.104 where the (one dimensional) HHH measurements are carried according to source addresses. In this case, the packet arrival is translated into the following five heavy hitters update operations: 101.102.103.104101.102.103.104101.102.103.104, 101.102.103.âˆ—formulae-sequence101.102.103101.102.103.*, 101.102.âˆ—formulae-sequence101.102101.102.*, 101.âˆ—formulae-sequence101101.*, andÂ âˆ—*. Finally, HHHs are identified by calculating the heavy hitters of each separate heavy hitters algorithm.

HFAST is derived by replacing the underlying heavy hitters algorithm inÂ [36] from Space Saving with heapÂ [35] to FAST. This asymptotically improves the update complexity from Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡(1Ïµ))ğ‘‚ğ»1italic-ÏµO\left(H\log\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)\right) to Oâ€‹(H)ğ‘‚ğ»O\left(H\right), where Hğ»H is the size of the hierarchy. Since the analysis ofÂ [36] is indifferent to the internal implementation of the heavy hitters algorithm, no analysis is required for HFAST.

Finally, we note that a hierarchical heavy hitters algorithm on sliding windows can be constructed using the work ofÂ [36] by replacing each space saving instance with our WFAST. The complexity of the proposed algorithm is Oâ€‹(HÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-ÏµO\left(\frac{H}{\epsilon}\right) space and Oâ€‹(H)ğ‘‚ğ»O\left(H\right) update time. To our knowledge, there is no prior work for this problem.

7 Evaluation

Our evaluation is performed on an Intel i7-5500U CPU with a clock speed of 2.4GHz, 16 GB RAM and a Windows 8.1 operating system. We compare our C++ prototypes to the following alternatives:

Count Min Sketch (CMS)Â [15] â€“ a sketch based solution that can only solve the volume estimation problem.

Space Saving Heap (SSH) â€“ a heap based implementationÂ [12] of Space SavingÂ [35] that has a logarithmic runtime complexity.

Hierarchical Space Saving Heap (HSSH) â€“ a hierarchical heavy hitters algorithmÂ [36] that uses SSH as a building block and operates in Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡(1Îµ))ğ‘‚ğ»1ğœ€O(H\log(\frac{1}{\varepsilon})) complexity.

Full Ancestry â€“ a trie based HHH algorithm suggested byÂ [14], which operates in Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡Ïµâ€‹N)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-Ïµğ‘O\left(H\log{\epsilon N}\right) complexity.

Partial Ancestry â€“ a trie based HHH algorithm suggested byÂ [14], which operates in Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡Ïµâ€‹N)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-Ïµğ‘O\left(H\log{\epsilon N}\right) complexity and is considered faster than Full Ancestry.

Related work implementations were taken from open source libraries released byÂ [11] for streams and byÂ [36] for hierarchical heavy hitters. As we have no access to a concrete implementation of a competing sliding window protocol, we compare WFAST to Hung and Tingâ€™s algorithmÂ [27] by conservatively estimating the space needed by their approach. Each data point we report here is the average of 10 runs.

7.1 Datasets

Our evaluation includes the following datasets. The packet traces characteristics are summarized in TableÂ 3.

The CAIDA backbone Internet traces that monitor links in ChicagoÂ [24, 25] and San JoseÂ [22, 23]. A datacenter trace from a large universityÂ [7] and a trace of 436K YouTube video accessesÂ [10]. The weight of a video is its length inÂ seconds.

As shown in TableÂ 3, the impact of jumbo frames varies between backbone links. Yet, the weight of large packets increases over time in both. In the San Jose link, the number and volume of large packets have increased by 50% within a period of 6 months. In the Chicago link, large packets are still insignificant, but their number and volume have increased by 50% in two months.

7.2 Effect of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi on Runtime

Recall that smaller Ï•italic-Ï•\phi yields space efficiency while the runtime is proportional to 1Ï•1italic-Ï•\frac{1}{\phi}, i.e, smaller Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is expected to cause a slower runtime. In AppendixÂ B, we show runtime performance evaluation of FAST as a function of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi for three different Îµğœ€\varepsilon values (2âˆ’8,2âˆ’10,2âˆ’12superscript28superscript210superscript2122^{-8},2^{-10},2^{-12}). While we indeed obtained a speedup with larger Ï•italic-Ï•\phi values, increasing Ï•italic-Ï•\phi beyond a certain small threshold has little impact on performance. For the rest of our evaluation, we focus on Ï•=0.25italic-Ï•0.25\phi=0.25 that offers attractive space/time trade off, as well as on Ï•=4italic-Ï•4\phi=4 that yields higher performance at the expense of more space.

7.3 Speed vs. Space Tradeoff

To explain the tradeoff proposed by FAST, we measured the runtime of the various algorithms for a fixed error guarantee. Here, SSH and CMS are fully determined by the error guarantees (set to be Ïµ=2âˆ’8italic-Ïµsuperscript28\epsilon=2^{-8}) and thus have a single measurement point. CMS requires more counters as it uses 101010 rows of âŒˆe/ÏµâŒ‰ğ‘’italic-Ïµ\lceil e/\epsilon\rceil counters each, while SSH only requires 1/Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1/\epsilon. FAST can provide the same error guarantee for different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi values, which affects both runtime and the number of counters. Hence, FAST is represented by a curve. As FigureÂ 3 shows, in all traces, allocating a few additional counters to the 1/Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1/\epsilon required by SSH allows FAST to achieve higher throughput. Additionally, on all traces, FAST provides faster throughput than CMS with far fewer counters. While FAST has larger per counter overheads than CMS, its ID to counter mapping allows it to solve the Weighted Heavy Hitters problem that CMS cannot.

7.4 Operation Speed Comparison

FigureÂ 4 presents a comparative analysis of the operation speed of previous approaches. Recall that CMS is a probabilistic scheme; we configured it with a failure probability of 0.1%percent0.10.1\%. For FAST, we used two configurations: Ï•=4italic-Ï•4\phi=4 (4FAST) and Ï•=0.25italic-Ï•0.25\phi=0.25Â (0.25FAST).

As can be observed, 4FAST and 0.25FAST are considerably faster than the alternatives in Chicago16 and YouTube. In SanJose14 and SanJose13, SSH is as fast as 4FAST for a large Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (small number of counters). Yet, as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon decreases and the number of counters increases, SSH becomes slower due to its logarithmic complexity. In contrast, CMS is almost workload independent. When considering only previous work, in some workloads CMS is faster than SSH, mainly because SSHâ€™s performance is workload dependent.

7.5 Sliding Window

We evaluate WFAST compared to Hung and Tingâ€™s algorithmÂ [27], which is the only one that supports weighted updates on sliding windows. FigureÂ 5 shows the memory consumption of WFAST with parameters Ï•=4italic-Ï•4\phi=4Â andÂ Ï•=0.25italic-Ï•0.25\phi=0.25 (4WFAST, 0.25FAST) compared to Hung and Tingâ€™s algorithm. All algorithms are configured to provide the same worst case error guarantee. As shown, WFAST is up to 100 times more space efficient than Hung and Tingâ€™s algorithm. Sadly, we could not obtain an implementation of Hung and Tingâ€™s algorithm and thus do not compare its runtime to WFAST. However, WFAST improves their update complexity from Oâ€‹(AÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ´italic-ÏµO(\frac{A}{\epsilon}), where Ağ´A is the average packet size, to Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1).

FigureÂ 6 shows the operation speed of WFAST for different window sizes and different Îµğœ€\varepsilon values. There is little dependence in window size and Îµğœ€\varepsilon with the exception of the DC1 dataset. In this dataset, since the average and maximal packet sizes are similar, the inner working of WFAST causes overflows to be more frequent when Îµğœ€\varepsilon is close to the window size. Thus, to achieve similar performance as the other traces one needs sufficiently large window size in this trace.

7.6 Hierarchical Heavy Hitters

In FigureÂ 7, we evaluate the speed of our HFAST compared to the algorithm ofÂ [36], which is denoted by HSSH, as well as the Partial Ancestry and Full Ancestry algorithms byÂ [14]. We used the library ofÂ [36] for their own HSSH implementation as well as for the Partial Ancestry and Full Ancestry implementations. Since the library was released for Linux, we used a different machine for our HFAST evaluation. Specifically, we used a Dell 730 server running Ubuntu 16.04.01 release. The server has 128GB of RAM and an Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2667 v4 @ 3.20GHz processor.

We used two dimensional source/destination hierarchies in byte granularity, where networks IDs are assumed to be 8, 16 or 24 bits long. The weight of each packet is its byte volume, including both the payload size and the header size. As depicted, HFAST is up to 7 times faster than the best alternative and at least 2.4 times faster in every data point. It appears that for large Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon values, HSSH is faster than the Partial and Full Ancestry algorithms. Yet, for small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon values, all previous algorithms operate in similar speed.

8 Discussion

In this paper, we presented algorithms for estimating per flow traffic volume in streams, sliding windows and hierarchical domains. Our algorithms offer both asymptotic and empirical improvements for these problems.

For streams, FAST processes packets in constant time while being asymptotically space optimal. This is enabled by our novel approach of maintaining only a partial order between counters. An evaluation over real-world traffic traces has yielded a speed improvement of up to 2.4X compared to previous work.

In the sliding window case, we showed that WFAST works reasonably fast and offers 100x reduction in required space, bringing sliding windows to the realm of possibility. For a given error of Wâ‹…Mâ‹…Ïµâ‹…ğ‘Šğ‘€italic-ÏµW\cdot M\cdot\epsilon, WFAST requires Oâ€‹(1Ïµ)ğ‘‚1italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\right) counters while previous work uses Oâ€‹(AÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ´italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{A}{\epsilon}}\right), where Ağ´A is the average packet size. Moreover, WFAST runs in constant time while previous work runs in Oâ€‹(AÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ´italic-ÏµO\left({\frac{A}{\epsilon}}\right).

For hierarchical domains, we presented HFAST that requires Oâ€‹(HÏµ)ğ‘‚ğ»italic-ÏµO(\frac{H}{\epsilon}) space and has Oâ€‹(H)ğ‘‚ğ»O(H) update complexity. This improves over the Oâ€‹(Hâ€‹logâ¡1Ïµ)ğ‘‚ğ»1italic-ÏµO\left(H\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right) update complexity of previous work. Additionally, we demonstrated a speedup of 2.4X-7X on real Internet traces. To our knowledge, there is no prior work on that problem and we plan to examine its possible applications in the future. The code of FAST is available as open sourceÂ [2].

We thank Yechiel Kimchi for helpful code optimizationÂ suggestions.

Proof of LemmaÂ 5

Proof A.12.

As mentioned before, FAST utilizes the SOS data structure that answers queries in Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1). Updates are a bit more complex as we need to handle weights and thus may be required to move the flow more than once, upon a counter increase. Whenever we wish to increase the value of a counter (LineÂ 3 and LineÂ 8), we need to remove the item from its current group and place it in a group that has the increased cğ‘c value. This means that for increasing a counter by nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}, we have to traverse at most nğ‘›n groups until we find the correct location.
